posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked:
Our team has two coders who are relatively new to using all of the resources our team has used in the past. Our main issue currently is that when continuously driving, the robot veers off course in sort of an arc shape. We have tried resetting the Angle Offsets, using LockTite on the magnets, swapping from Robot Centric to Field Centric, swapping the swerve drive motors (we use NEOs), and swapping the motor controllers (SparkMAXs), but nothing has remedied the issue. Competition is in a few days, and we have sort of hit a brick wall in terms of ideas to fix this. All of the solutions we read were either different issues, or the solutions simply didn’t work.

Quick Clarification: The Swerve Drives seem to be offsetting as a whole, and we are pretty sure it is a code issue, not a mechanical one.

posts.name: Tyson Whelan
posts.cooked:
Do you mean the entire robot is slowly rotating without manually rotating it? My team has always had this “problem” where the robot rotates less than a degree a second but our driver has gotten used to it. I’m not sure if this is a widely experienced issue but we’ve had it throughout all three swerve libraries we’ve used in the past 2 years.

Are you planning on using robot relative at competition? I would assume this problem would make a much bigger difference when using robot relative, but with field relative it hasn’t done much for our team since our driver is constantly on the rotation stick and is subconsciously adjusting for this drift.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked:
We have the same issue and haven’t solved it either AFAIK.  It also affects autonomous, where the driver can’t correct.  Is it possible there’s a power or traction imbalance where one module is dragging compared to the others?  That’s the next thing I can think of after the other items you’ve listed as tested.

Edit: this could be more likely than I realized - we did a connections check on Monday and found at least one drive motor with a poor Wago splice.  I’ll have to check in today to see if the issue went away.

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked: We do believe it is a power/speed imbalance in one swerve module, we are going to try telling one of the modules to move at a higher speed and see if it corrects it even slightly.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked: definitely curious to hear how that goes

posts.name: Aiden Keegan
posts.cooked:
It seems like you are dealing with a pretty common known swerve drive issue. Check out this post for a more comprehensive (and math-heavy) explanation of the issue. To compensate for the drift while translating, my team runs a simple P controller on the rotation so that we constantly align to our last gyro heading. Check out our build blog and our github for more details

Essentially it is this

subconsciously adjusting for this drift

but done automatically instead of by the driver

link_counts.title: Whitepaper: Swerve Drive Skew and Second Order Kinematics

posts.name: Gage Caswell
posts.cooked: We just tested the new swerve drive speeds and everything is working as it should! One module was just off in its speed.

posts.name: Jake Potter
posts.cooked: Ours is almost definitely rotating when it’s not supposed to, as it moves linearly.  Probably more of what Aiden posted.

posts.custom_user_title: 1554 Mentor, 694 Alum, LRI, FIRST Long Island RPC

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked:
Did you have any bounce back with your rotation controller after a fast rotate and sudden stop by the driver?

We have a similar heading control setup but inertia of the robot would make it continue rotating a bit after the rotate stick returned to zero (or below the deadband). Then tne controlller would snap the robot back.

To avoid this we monitor angular velocity as well and update the target heading if the rotate stick is zero OR the angular velocity is above a threshold value.  The threshold  is low enough to catch the continued rotation from inertia but is high enough that it doesn’t trigger heading updates when experiencing normal drift.

posts.name: Aiden Keegan
posts.cooked: We haven’t ran into this iirc, but that could very well just be because our robot doesn’t have that much momentum relative to yours. I like that fix, if we start running into this in the future we’ll try that out.

posts.name: Ori Sharim
posts.cooked: Are you doing PID on the heading angle?

posts.name: acastagna
posts.cooked: Our driver is very agressive with the joystick which also contributes. It’s only an issue with fast rotations and sudden stops by the driver
